title: How to Calculate the Mean: Step-By-Step Guide

steps.title: Determine the set of values you want to average.
steps.content: Determine the set of values you want to average. [3] X Research source v161418_b01. Tuesday, January 24, 2023. These numbers can be big or small, and there can be as many of them as you want. [4] X Research source Just make sure you are using real numbers and not variables. Example: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.

steps.title: Add your values together to find the sum.
steps.content: Add your values together to find the sum. You can use a calculator, by hand, or a spreadsheet application to do so. [5] X Research source Example: 2 + 3 + 4 + 5 + 6 = 20 {\displaystyle 2+3+4+5+6=20}

steps.title: Count the number of values in your group.
steps.content: Count the number of values in your group. Count all of the numbers added up. Identical values should still be counted, meaning if you have values that repeat in your set, each one still counts in determining your total. Do not include the sum (answer) of all the numbers added up when counting the quantity of the values. [6] X Research source Example: 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 make for a total of five values.

steps.title: Divide the sum of the set by the number of values.
steps.content: Divide the sum of the set by the number of values. The result is the mean (a type of average) of your set. This implies that if each number in your set was the mean, they would add up to the same total. [7] X Research source Example: 20 / 5 = 4 {\displaystyle 20/5=4} . Therefore, 4 is the mean of the numbers. You can check your calculations by multiplying the mean by the number of values in the set. In this case, multiply 4 {\displaystyle 4} (the mean) by the 5 {\displaystyle 5} (the number of values in the set) and your result will be 20 {\displaystyle 20} ( 4 âˆ— 5 = 20 {\displaystyle 4*5=20} ).
